column1: #Text=## Reliable Fidelity and Diversity Metrics for Generative Models (ICML 2020)
#Text=[Paper: Reliable Fidelity and Diversity Metrics for Generative Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2002.09797)
#Text=Muhammad Ferjad Naeem <sup>1,3*</sup>, Seong Joon Oh<sup>2*</sup>, Yunjey Choi<sup>1</sup>,
#Text=Devising indicative evaluation metrics for the image generation task remains an open problem.
#Text=The most widely used metric for measuring the similarity between real and generated images has been the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) score.

#Text=Because it does not differentiate the _fidelity_ and _diversity_ aspects of the generated images, recent papers have introduced variants of precision and recall metrics to diagnose those properties separately.
#Text=In this paper, we show that even the latest version of the precision and recall (Kynkäänniemi et al., 2019) metrics are not reliable yet.
#Text=For example, they fail to detect the match between two identical distributions, they are not robust against outliers, and the evaluation hyperparameters are selected arbitrarily.
#Text=We propose **density and coverage** metrics that solve the above issues.
#Text=We analytically and experimentally show that density and coverage provide more interpretable and reliable signals for practitioners than the existing metrics.
#Text=where the manifold is the defined as
#Text=is the ball around the point `x` with radius `r`.
#Text=is the distance to the kth-nearest neighbour.
#Text=### Why are DC better than PR?
#Text=Because of the real outlier sample, the manifold is overestimated.
#Text=The real and fake samples are identical across left and right.
